name: PC 9801 E
keyboard: Complete full-stroke keyboard with function keys, numeric keypad, editing keys
ports: Floppy Disk Drive, RS-232C, Printer, C-bus slot x 6
description:
The PC-9801E belongs to the famous NEC PC-98xx family. This is not an IBM PC compatible system. Its architecture is original.

Unlike the PC-9801F, the PC-9801 has no built-in disk drives.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> :-)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #5 (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">If you could talk to Thomas Edison, he'd tell you what it was like to turn the light on in 1879. You could tell him about some bright idea of the 20th century... particularly, a technological phenomenon that can handle everything from solar heat control to lighting you home via voice command. The Apple personal computer...<br> ... With Apple, Edison could've written a program to determine why some filaments burned longer than others...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advertising for the MZ 1500 (with the Quick Disk drive) in a Japanese magazine.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  ACORN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> This attractive package inherits the traditions of the famous Model B BBC microcomputer which is used by children in almost every school in the United Kingdom as well as colleges, hospitals, laboratories, factories, offices, banks and shops. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://club.pep.ne.jp/~p.katsu/pasocata/index.html">P.KATSU</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMTEXT BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right arrow, advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Redesigned front panel. Totally synchronous logic design. Same switch and LED arrangement as original Altair 8800. New back.lit Duralith (laminated plastic and mylar, bonded to aluminum) dress panel with multi.color graphics. New longer, flat toggle switches. Five new functions stored on front panel PROM inc1uding: DISPLAY ACCUMULATOR (displays contents of accumulator), LOAD ACCUMULATOR (loads contents of the 8 data switches (A7.AO) into accumulator), OUTPUT ACCUMULATOR (Outputs contents of accumulator to I/O device addressed by the upper 8 address switches), INPUT ACCUMULATOR (inputs to the accumulator from the I/O device), and SLOW (causes program execution at a rate of about 5 cycles per second for program debugging). <br><br> Two, 34 conductor ribbon cable assemblies. Connects front panel board to front panel interface board. Eliminates need for complicated front panel/bus wiring. <br><br> New front panel interface board buffers all lines to and from 8800b bus. <br><br> Rugged, commercial grade Optima cabinet. <br><br> Full 18 slot motherboard. <br><br> New CPU board with 8080A microprocessor and Intel 8224 clock generator and 8216 bus drivers. Clock pulse widths and phasing as well as frequency are crystal controlled. Compatible with all current Altair 8800 software and hardware!. <br><br> New, heavy duty power supply: +8 volts at 18 amps, + 18 volts at 2 amps, -18 volts at 2 amps. 110 volt or 220 volt operation (50/60 Hz). Primary tapped for either high or low line operation.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... With the knowledge that Mitsubishi is the largest manufacturer of Mainframe computers in Japan, those in the know will immediately recognise the true potential of the Mitsubishi F-series...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Isn't this funky ??!! I love it. We can see here the handle  of the H1.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIL ORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Computer assisted mail-order <br><br> As soon as the home computers could communicate easily through modem with large computer sites, the major mail-order companies had the idea to sell products to the computers users. This  concept was facilitated in France by the free distribution of the 'Minitel' Videotex terminal that was gradually integrated into home computers. The success gained by this system in France did not have any equal in the rest of the world.  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juan Antonio Maestre for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Quite impressive, non ?!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/"><img src="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/ban_pc1s.gif" border="0"></a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #6 (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DMS-15</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983 advert.<br><br> The DMS-15 is a DMS-3/F with a built-in 15 MB hard disk.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What makes the QX-10 the most remarkably usable computer to date is a unique software system called VALDOC...<br><br> ... VALDOCS may be all the software you will never need. Right out of the box, it's a sophisticated <i>word processor</i>; an <i>information indexer</i> for easy acces to files; an <i>electronic mail system</i>;a <i>calculator</i>;an <i>apointment book</i> and <i>notepad</i>; and a <i>high resolution business graph drawing system</i>...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHRISTMAS 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"><b> A smart investment</b><br> Radio Shack's popular TRS-80 Color Computer is now on sale. You can get this complete, versatile system with a 16 K-byte memory and Standard Color BASIC language for only $299.95 (Cat. No. 26-3004, reg. $399.95). It's the affordable way for the entire family to start computing.</font><br><br> The Extended BASIC - 16 KB version was priced $399.95<br> The 32 KB version was priced $549.95.</blockquote>
